title: Loss Analysis of Magnetic Components for a Solid-State-Transformer
abstract: Recently, because of research and development into SiC power devices, power converter circuits such as high-power isolated DC-DC converters (dual active bridge) using medium-frequency (MF) transformers have been proposed. The converter circuit requires the MF transformer and inductors, but these magnetic components dominate the volume of the circuit. To realize a high-power-density isolated DC-DC converter, it is necessary to analyze the losses in the MF transformer and inductors. In this paper, an iron loss calculation method based on the improved generalized Steinmetz equation (iGSE) is presented. To analyze the iron loss in detail, an analysis method which divides the iron loss into the hysteresis loss and the eddy-current loss is also presented. Further, this paper presents a loss separation procedure for the iron loss in the MF transformer and inductors. In this analysis, the iron loss analysis is performed for different operation modes of the DC-DC converter. Finally, the validity of the separation procedure is confirmed by both analytical and experimental results.

Recently, because of research and development into SiC power devices, power converter circuits such as high-power
isolated DC-DC converters (dual active bridge) using medium-frequency (MF) transformers have been proposed. The
converter circuit requires the MF transformer and inductors, but these magnetic components dominate the volume of
the circuit. To realize a high-power-density isolated DC-DC converter, it is necessary to analyze the losses in the MF
transformer and inductors.
In this paper, an iron loss calculation method based on the improved generalized Steinmetz equation (iGSE) is pre-
sented. To analyze the iron loss in detail, an analysis method which divides the iron loss into the hysteresis loss and
the eddy-current loss is also presented. Further, this paper p resents a loss separation procedure for the iron loss in the
MF transformer and inductors. In this analysis, the iron loss analysis is performed for diﬀerent operation modes of the
DC-DC converter. Finally, the validity of the separation procedure is conﬁrmed by both analytical and experimental
results.
Keywords: DC-DC converter, iron loss, solid state transformer, medium-frequency transformer
1. Introduction
Recently, a solid-state transformer for medium-voltage ap-
plications has been discussed for use in next-generation elec-
trical grids such as smart grids (1) (2). A typical candidate for
the solid-state transformer is an isolated DC-DC converter
(dual active bridge) with a medium-frequency (MF) trans-
former; high-power isolated DC-DC converters have been
proposed
(3)–(6). Isolated DC-DC converters for railway ap-
plications and power distribution systems have been dis-
cussed
(7). Furthermore, a DC-DC converter with a voltage
of 2.5 kV and a transmission power of 200 kW has been de-
veloped
(8).
To realize a high-power isolated DC-DC converter, a re-
duction in volume and higher eﬃciency of the magnetic com-
ponents, especially the MF transformer and inductors, are
needed because these components dominate the volume in
DC-DC converters. However, a reduction in volume results
in higher powers and higher loss densities in the transformer,
which may cause serious problems such as thermal limita-
tions in the magnetic core. Because of the thermal limitation,
it is necessary to calculate the iron losses for the MF trans-
former and inductors. The total loss and isolation materials of
the MF transformer for the DC-DC converters have been dis-
cussed in many papers
(9) (10). However, no analysis procedure
for the iron loss depending on the circuit operation of the MF
transformer and the inductors has ever been presented. The
operation frequency of the solid-state transformer is normally
set to over 10 kHz. The voltage waveform is not sinusoidal,
but rectangular; the excited voltage waveform depends on the
circuit operation. As a result, a conventional iron loss analy-
sis procedure based on the loss data supplied by the datasheet

for a sinusoidal waveform does not apply to the magnetic
components of the DC-DC converter. Therefore, an analy-
sis procedure for the iron losses in the magnetic components
in a solid-state transformer should be developed. To design
the MF transformer, iron loss analysis methods, which show
the iron loss characteristics under the actual operating condi-
tions of the DC-DC converter, are presented in this paper. In
addition, the authors present an iron loss separation method
that divides the iron loss into the hysteresis loss and the eddy-
current loss. If these two components of the iron loss are
made clear, a suitable core shape or material for a DC-DC
converter will be proposed. Speciﬁcally, the initial design of
the core, such as material, thickness, and structure, depends
on the sinusoidal voltage excitations. However, the excited
voltage waveform of the DC-DC converter depends on the
operation conditions; thus, the iron loss calculation and its
separation should be discussed.
In this paper, a simple method for iron loss calculation,
based on the iGSE and specialized to evaluate the isolated
DC-DC converter, is shown. In Ref. (11), an iron loss analy-
sis method called i
2GSE is proposed. This method, based on
the Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert equation, can calculate the iron
loss under rectangular excitation more accurately than iGSE.
However, to calculate the iron loss of the MF transformer
used in the DC-DC converter by i
2GSE, the actual magnetiz-
ing voltage waveform is needed. In this research, a simple
analysis method for the iron loss is considered. Therefore,
the simpler method, iGSE, is used for the iron loss.
To analyze the iron loss in detail, this paper proposes an
iron loss calculation method that can divide the iron loss into
hysteresis loss and eddy-current loss. Moreover, the total loss
analysis of the magnetic components including the inductor
in the isolated DC-DC converter is also presented.
To conﬁrm the validity of these analysis methods, ana-
lytical and experimental results will be presented. In this

3. Iron Loss Separation into Hysteresis Loss and
Eddy-Current Loss
The iron loss separation into hysteresis loss and other
losses has previously been presented for the case of using
an inductor for switching ripple reduction ﬁlters under the
DC excitation condition
(13). However, the ratios of hysteresis
loss and eddy-current loss to the total iron losses of the MF
transformer are unclear.
Generally, to analyze the iron losses of a transformer un-
der sinusoidal excitation, a separation equation for hysteresis
loss and eddy-current loss is used
(14):
Piron =σh fB max

the B-H analyzer under sinusoidal excitation. The ﬁrst part
of the equation represents the hysteresis loss and the second

4. Total Loss Analysis of the MF Transformer
and the Inductors
To design the MF transformer and inductors for the DC-
DC converter, the total loss of these magnetic components,
including the copper loss, should be known, because the mag-
netic components dominate the volume of the DC-DC con-
verter. Therefore, if the total loss is known for the various
operation conditions of the DC-DC converter, a design that
optimally reduces the losses of the magnetic components can
be created.

5. Experimental Results
This section presents the experimental results based on the
methods proposed in this paper. The e ﬀects of the core tem-
perature on the iron loss were reported in (16). From the mea-

iron and copper loss

6. Conclusion
This paper presented an analysis method based on the
iGSE of the losses in the magnetic components in an isolated
DC-DC converter for solid-state transformer.
The results showed that the iron loss when using the iGSE
corresponds to the experimental results, and that the analy-
sis results when using the iron loss separation method also
correspond to the experimental results.
Furthermore, in this paper, a total loss analysis method
for the magnetic components, including the inductors, is pre-
sented. The validity of the method is conﬁrmed by comparing
its results to the experimental results. Using this method, the
total loss design of the magnetic components of the isolated
DC-DC converter is possible.
